descriptions.description: • Can introduce him/herself and others and can ask and answer questions about personal details such as where he/she lives, people he/she knows and things he/she has.
• Can understand and use familiar everyday expressions and very basic phrases aimed at the satisfaction of needs of a concrete type.
• Can interact in a simple way provided the other person talks slowly and clearly and is prepared to help.
Welcome / Icebreaker
Let's get to know each other / one another better.
By the end of this lesson, students will be able to say hello and make introductions using my, your, his, and her.

items.label: Flipped Classroom • What's your name? (Cycle 1)
Classwork • What's your name? (Cycle 1)
Homework • What's your name? (Cycle 1)

descriptions.description: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to say good-bye and exchange contact information using subject pronouns and the verb be.

items.label: Flipped Classroom • What's your name? (Cycle 2)
Classwork • What's your name? (Cycle 2)
Homework • What's your name? (Cycle 2)
Homework • Basic Grammar in Use • Unit 1

descriptions.description: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to identify and discuss personal and classroom objects using the articles a/ an, plurals, this / these, and it / they.

items.label: Flipped Classroom • Where are my keys? (Cycle 1)
Classwork • Where are my keys? (Cycle 1)
Homework • Where are my keys? (Cycle 1)

descriptions.description: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to discuss the location of items using yes/ no and where questions with be, the article the, and prepositions of place.

items.label: Flipped Classroom • Where are my keys? (Cycle 2)
Classwork • Where are my keys? (Cycle 2)
Homework • Where are my keys? (Cycle 2)

• identify areas that need improvement

descriptions.description: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to discuss work and free- time clothes and colors using possessive adjectives, possessive pronouns, and possessives with names.
